newsitem.title: CHINA: China seen turning to Middle East for oil imports.
newsitem.headline: China seen turning to Middle East for oil imports.

text.p: China will likely turn to Middle East countries for crude oil imports as its own domestic output lags behind domestic demand, Western and Chinese oil industry executives said on Tuesday.
"Middle Eastern crudes will be (China's) predominant import and the major use will be for petrochemical feedstock," said a British Petroleum Co Plc executive.
China's crude oil imports are forecast to reach 1.4 million barrels per day by 2005 and petrochemical demand could represent up to 70 percent of imported crude, he said.
Crude production in the Asia-Pacific region is expected to be relatively flat for the next several years with only Indonesia having a surplus available for China, the executive said.

Although crude oil from some western African countries will be available for China's import needs, Middle Eastern oil is more suitable for petrochemical feedstock due to its high naphtha and paraffin content, and easy availability, he said.
Saudi Arabian, Iranian and Omani crudes would be the most likely choices to fill the gap, being most suitable in terms of quality and price.
"There is a good fit between the petrochemical side and (future) crude imports," said the BP official.
"Some of the refiners will have to modify for high sulphur crudes, but that is already happening."
Jiang Lu, an official at China Petrochemical Corp, said he agreed with this assessment.
"This is already the case," he said.
Many coastal refiners are already installing capacity to handle high sulphur crudes, among them facilities in Maoming, in Guangdong province, and the Zhenhai refinery in Ningbo in Zhejiang province.
China's own domestic crudes tend to be low in sulphur.
